name: Networking Fundamentals
description: Master the building blocks of networking: IP addresses, subnets, routing, and DNS. These concepts are the foundation for everything in cloud infrastructure.

learning_steps.title: IP Addresses Explained
learning_steps.description: Understand IPv4 addresses, octets, and how binary relates to IP addressing. Know the difference between public and private IP ranges (10.x.x.x, 172.16-31.x.x, 192.168.x.x).

learning_steps.title: Subnetting Made Simple
learning_steps.description: Learn CIDR notation (/24, /16, etc.), subnet masks, and how to calculate network ranges. Practice subnetting until it becomes second nature.

learning_steps.title: Subnet Practice Tool
learning_steps.description: Use this interactive tool to practice subnetting. Aim to answer subnet questions quickly and accurately before moving on.

learning_steps.title: How Routing Works
learning_steps.description: Understand how packets travel between networks: routing tables, default gateways, and how routers make forwarding decisions.

learning_steps.title: Network Address Translation
learning_steps.description: Learn how NAT allows private IP addresses to communicate with the internet. Understand SNAT, DNAT, and port forwarding.

learning_steps.title: DNS Explained
learning_steps.description: Understand how DNS resolves domain names: recursive resolvers, root servers, authoritative servers, and common record types (A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, TXT).

learning_steps.title: Using dig and nslookup
learning_steps.description: Practice using dig and nslookup to query DNS records. Try: dig google.com, dig +trace google.com, nslookup -type=MX gmail.com

learning_steps.title: Networking Fundamentals Playlist
learning_steps.description: NetworkChuck's engaging overview of networking concepts. Great for reinforcing what you've learned.

questions.prompt: Explain the difference between public and private IP addresses, and describe when NAT is needed.
scenario_seeds: Your colleague asks why their home network devices all show 192.168.x.x addresses when they check online what is my IP and see something different.
You're setting up a development environment and need to explain why containers can communicate on 172.17.x.x but can't be reached directly from the internet.
A junior developer is confused about why their local API works on 127.0.0.1 but teammates can't access it.
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain private IP ranges AND that public IPs are internet-routable AND NAT translates between them for internet access.

questions.prompt: Walk me through what happens when you type a URL in your browser and press enter, focusing on the DNS resolution process.
scenario_seeds: Your website works for some users but not others, and you suspect DNS caching issues. Explain the resolution chain.
A new domain you registered isn't resolving yet. Walk through where the delay might be occurring.
You need to explain to a teammate why changing a DNS record doesn't take effect immediately.
questions.grading_rubric: Must cover browser cache check AND recursive resolver query AND root/TLD/authoritative server hierarchy AND TTL caching.

test_knowledge_prompts: Quiz me on subnetting and CIDR notation
